docs.title: Jane
docs.text:
Zero‑side‑effect normalization and validation helpers for JavaScript.

Jane is a small, clarity‑first helper library for normalizing, validating, and safely parsing unknown input in JavaScript and TypeScript.

It’s built for developers who want predictable behavior, composable pipelines, and zero surprises — without schema systems, decorators, or framework lock‑in.

Jane is intentionally small. Intentionally explicit. Intentionally boring in all the right ways.

docs.title: Why Jane?
docs.text:
Most validation libraries try to be everything: schema builders, type generators, transformers, parsers, refiners, and runtime type systems.

Jane takes the opposite approach.

Jane is:

  • Pure: No side effects, no hidden mutations.
  • Deterministic: Same input, same output, every time.
  • Composable: Build pipelines with pipe().
  • Zero‑dependency: No runtime weight.
  • Framework‑agnostic: Works in Node, serverless, workers, Express, Fastify, Bun, Deno.
  • Focused: Normalization → validation → result.

If you want a dependable “standard library” for data sanity, Jane is your girl.

docs.title: Who is Jane for?
docs.text:
Jane is designed for developers who:

  • Prefer explicit, predictable behavior over magic.
  • Want pure functions instead of schema DSLs.
  • Need safe parsing for config, requests, queries, and internal boundaries.
  • Value clarity and maintainability in long‑lived codebases.
  • Dislike validators that throw.
  • Want small, composable building blocks instead of monolithic schemas.

If you’ve ever written your own tiny normalizers and validators because existing libraries felt too heavy — Jane was built for you.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: npm install @steven-clements/jane

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
Documentation is available at:

  • Project overview
  • Reference
  • Contributing

docs.title: License
docs.text:
Jane is licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0.

http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0

docs.title: Author
docs.text:
Steven "Chris" Clements

Designed for clarity, composability, and long‑term maintainability.

docs.title: Follow the development workflow
docs.text:
Jane follows a clarity‑first, contract‑driven workflow. Every change begins with an explicit description of the intended behavior before any implementation work is done.

The workflow is:

  1. Write a reference topic

    Describe the module’s purpose, inputs, outputs, constraints, and edge cases in docs/reference/.

    The reference topic is the human‑readable contract.

  2. Write the tests

    Translate your reference topic into executable expectations using Vitest.

    Tests should cover:

    • Expected behavior.
    • Invalid inputs.
    • Edge cases.
    • Type‑level expectations (if applicable).

    Tests are the executable contract.

  3. Write the implementation

    Implement the module so that it satisfies the spec and passes all tests.

    Keep modules small, explicit, and free of side effects.

  4. Update documentation

    If the change affects public behavior, update the relevant docs in docs/.

  5. Commit using semantic messages

    Use Conventional Commits to ensure automated releases and changelog updates:

    • feat: for new features
    • fix: for bug fixes
    • docs: for documentation changes
    • refactor: for internal changes
    • test: for test‑only changes
    • chore: for non‑code tasks

This workflow ensures that behavior is defined before it is implemented, tests reflect the intended contract, and the codebase remains predictable and maintainable.

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
• Development workflow
  • Restricted files and directories

docs.title: Restricted repo files
docs.text:
This project uses automated tooling for releases, formatting, documentation, and configuration.

To keep the repository stable and predictable, certain files must not be edited in pull requests unless explicitly requested by a maintainer.

docs.title: Do not modify these files
docs.text:
• CHANGELOG.md: Automatically generated by the release pipeline. Any manual edits will be overwritten.
  • CODEOWNERS: Defines review and approval rules. Changes require maintainer approval and are not accepted through general PRs.

  • LICENSE: Legal document. Only maintainers may update it.

  • Release and automation configs:

These files are part of the automated release and CI/CD pipeline and must remain stable:

  • .releaserc or release.config.*
  • .github/workflows/*
  • package.json (release‑related fields)

  • semantic-release configuration

  • Formatting and linting configs:

These define the project’s formatting and linting rules:

  • prettier.config.*
  • eslint.config.*
  • .editorconfig
  • tsconfig.json

  • vitest.config.*

  • Root‑level configuration files:

Unless a maintainer requests a change, do not modify files at the repository root (except README.md and mkdocs.yml).

docs.title: Allowed areas for contributions
docs.text:
Most contributions should be limited to:

  • mkdocs.yml — documentation site navigation
  • README.md — General project information (raise the bar!).
  • src/ — implementation
  • tests/ — test suites
  • docs/ — documentation
  • coverage/ — generated coverage artifacts (rarely edited manually)

docs.title: Exceptions
docs.text:
If a change to a restricted file is required to fix a bug, improve documentation, or resolve a configuration issue, please open an issue first.

A maintainer will confirm whether the change is appropriate before a PR is opened.

This policy ensures:

  • Consistent automation.
  • Predictable releases.
  • Stable contributor experience.
  • Clear separation between code and infrastructure.

docs.title: Reference
docs.text:
The Reference section documents every helper in Jane. Each page includes a clear description, the function signature, parameter tables, return shapes, examples, and notes. All helpers follow the same predictable structure so you can find what you need quickly.

Use this section when you already understand the concepts and workflows, and you need precise details about a specific helper.

docs.title: What’s included
docs.text: Jane includes several categories of helpers. Each category has its own index page and detailed entries for every function.

docs.title: Type guards
docs.text:
Helpers that check types and shapes without throwing.

Use these when you need safe branching logic.

Learn more

docs.title: How to read this section
docs.text:
Each helper is documented with:

  • A short description.
  • The function signature.
  • A parameter table.
  • The return shape.
  • Examples.
  • Notes and edge cases.

Every entry is self‑contained and predictable. You can read them in any order.

docs.title: Type guards
docs.text:
Type guards help you safely branch logic and validate shapes without throwing exceptions. They return simple booleans and never mutate input. Use them when you need to confirm a value’s type before running a normalization or validation step.

Type guards are pure, predictable, and consistent. They make your workflows easier to read and easier to reason about.

docs.title: Available type guards
docs.text:
Each type guard has its own reference page with examples and edge cases.

  • isArray: Checks whether a value is an array.
  • isBigInteger: Checks whether a value is a bigint.
  • isBoolean: Checks whether a value is a boolean.
  • isDate: Checks whether a value is a date.
  • isEnumValue: Checks whether a value is an enum value.
  • isFiniteNumber: Checks whether a value is a finite number.
  • isFunction: Checks whether a value is a function.
  • isInteger: Checks whether a value is an integer.
  • isNonEmptyString: Checks whether a value is a non‑empty string.
  • isNonNegativeNumber: Checks whether a value is a number.
  • isNumber: Checks whether a value is a number.
  • isObject: Checks whether a value is an object.
  • isPlainObject: Checks whether a value is a plain object.
  • isPort: Checks whether a value is a valid TCP/UDP port number.
  • isPromise: Checks whether a value is a promise.
  • isRecord: Checks whether a value is a record.
  • isString: Checks whether a value is a string.
  • isTimestamp: Checks whether a value is a timestamp.

docs.title: When to use type guards
docs.text:
Use type guards when:

  • You need to branch logic based on type.
  • You want to avoid exceptions.
  • You want predictable behavior in pipelines.
  • You need to confirm a value’s shape before normalization.
  • You want to write defensive code without clutter.

Type guards are the simplest building blocks in Jane. They help you write clear, explicit workflows.

docs.title: isArray
docs.text: Checks whether a value is an array. This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is an array before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isArray(value: unknown): value is unknown[]

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The unknown value to check. Must be validated explicitly; no assumptions or coercion are applied.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is an array.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isArray([])              // true
isArray([1, 2, 3])       // true
isArray(["a", "b"])      // true

isArray({})              // false
isArray(null)            // false
isArray("hello")         // false
isArray(123)             // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper uses Array.isArray internally.
  • Use normalizeArray if you need to ensure a value becomes an array.
  • Use normalizeStringArray if you need an array of strings.
  • Use validateArray if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isAsyncIterable
docs.text: Checks whether a value is async iterable. A value is async iterable if it is not null or undefined and has a callable [Symbol.asyncIterator] method. This matches the behavior of for await...of and other async iteration constructs.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isAsyncIterable<T = unknown>(value: unknown): value is AsyncIterable<T>

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must implement the async iterable protocol to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is async iterable.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
async function* gen() { yield 1 }
isAsyncIterable(gen())          // true

isAsyncIterable([])             // false
isAsyncIterable('abc')          // false
isAsyncIterable(null)           // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper checks only for the presence of a callable [Symbol.asyncIterator] method.
  • It does not attempt to call the async iterator.
  • Sync iterables are not considered async iterables.
  • Use validateAsyncIterable if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isBigInteger
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is a bigint. A bigint is a primitive numeric type that represents integers of arbitrary precision.

This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm bigint types before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isBigInteger(value: unknown): value is bigint

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. This helper returns true only for bigint primitives.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a bigint.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isBigInteger(10n)                     // true
isBigInteger(999999999999999999n)     // true

isBigInteger(10)                      // false
isBigInteger(3.14)                    // false
isBigInteger(NaN)                     // false
isBigInteger("123")                   // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not accept number values, even if they are integers. Use isInteger or isSafeInteger for number-based integer checks.
  • Bigints are always integers; fractional bigint values do not exist.
  • Use normalizeBigInteger if you need to convert values into bigints.
  • Use validateBigInteger if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isBoolean
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a boolean. This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm boolean types before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isBoolean(value: unknown): value is boolean

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown This helper performs a strict typeof check and only returns true for primitive boolean values.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a boolean.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isBoolean(true)        // true
isBoolean(false)       // true
isBoolean(0)           // false
isBoolean("true")      // false
isBoolean(null)        // false
isBoolean(undefined)   // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not coerce truthy or falsy values.
  • Use normalizeBoolean if you need to convert values into booleans.
  • Use validateBoolean if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isDate
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is a valid Date instance. This helper verifies two things:

  1. The value is actually a Date object (instanceof Date).
  2. The internal timestamp is valid (getTime() is not NaN).

It never throws and never mutates input.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text:
function isDate(value: unknown): value is Date
Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a Date instance with a valid timestamp to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a Date instance and its timestamp is valid.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isDate(new Date())                 // true
isDate(new Date("2020-01-01"))     // true

isDate(new Date("invalid"))        // false
isDate(Date.now())                 // false
isDate("2020-01-01")               // false
isDate(null)                       // false
isDate({})                         // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Invalid Date objects such as new Date("invalid") are rejected because their time value is NaN.
  • This helper does not attempt to parse or coerce values into dates.
  • Use normalizeDate if you need to convert values into Date instances.
  • Use validateDate if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isEnumValue
docs.text: Checks whether a value is one of the allowed enum values. This helper works with both numeric and string enums. It never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value belongs to a specific enum before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text:
function isEnumValue<T extends Record<string, unknown>>(
  enumObject: T,
  value: unknown
): value is T[keyof T]

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description enumObject Record<string, unknown> The enum-like object whose values define the allowed set. value unknown The value to check. Must match one of the enum’s values to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is included in Object.values(enumObject).
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
enum Color {
  Red = "red",
  Blue = "blue",
}

isEnumValue(Color, "red")     // true
isEnumValue(Color, "blue")    // true
isEnumValue(Color, "green")   // false
isEnumValue(Color, 123)       // false

enum Status {
  Active = 1,
  Disabled = 2,
}

isEnumValue(Status, 1)        // true
isEnumValue(Status, 3)        // false

For numeric enums, TypeScript generates reverse mappings, which means enum keys may also be treated as valid values.

Example:

enum Status {
  Active = 1,
  Disabled = 2,
}

// ["Active", "Disabled", 1, 2]
Object.values(Status)

isEnumValue(Status, "Active") // true

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Works with both string and numeric enums.
  • Uses Object.values(enumObject).includes(value) internally.
  • Use normalizeEnum if you need to convert values into enum values.
  • Use validateEnum if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isError
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is an Error object. This helper performs a strict instanceof check and never throws or mutates input. It accepts all native error types as well as custom error subclasses.

Note: isError uses a strict instanceof Error check. This means it may return false for Error objects created in a different execution context (for example, another realm such as an iframe).

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isError(value: unknown): value is Error

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be an Error instance (including subclasses and wrapper objects) to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is an Error.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isError(new Error())          // true
isError(new TypeError())      // true
isError(Object(new Error()))  // true

isError({ name: 'Error' })    // false
isError('Error')              // false
isError(null)                 // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper accepts wrapper objects because JavaScript treats them as genuine Error instances.
  • It accepts all native error types and custom subclasses.
  • Use normalizeError if you need to convert values into Error objects.
  • Use validateError if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isFiniteNumber
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a finite primitive number. A finite number is a number primitive that is not NaN, Infinity, or -Infinity. This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is suitable for arithmetic, normalization, or any domain where numeric finiteness is required.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isFiniteNumber(value: unknown): value is number

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a finite primitive number to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a finite primitive number.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isFiniteNumber(0)        // true
isFiniteNumber(3.14)     // true
isFiniteNumber(-100)     // true

isFiniteNumber(NaN)      // false
isFiniteNumber(Infinity) // false

isFiniteNumber("123")    // false
isFiniteNumber(1n)       // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper is stricter than isNumber, which accepts NaN, Infinity, and -Infinity.
  • Wrapper objects (for example, new Number(5)) are rejected because they are not number primitives.
  • Use isInteger if you need to confirm integer values.
  • Use normalizeFiniteNumber if you need to coerce values into finite numbers.
  • Use validateFiniteNumber if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isFunction
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a function. This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm callable values before running logic that expects a function.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text:
function isFunction(value: unknown): value is Function
Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a function (per JavaScript's typeof semantics), including class constructors, async functions, generator functions, and bound functions.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a function (including classes, async, generator, and built-in functions).
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
// Standard functions
isFunction(function () {})        // true
isFunction(() => {})              // true

// Async functions
isFunction(async function () {})  // true
isFunction(async () => {})        // true

// Generator functions
isFunction(function* () {})       // true

// Class constructors
class MyClass {}
isFunction(MyClass)               // true

// Bound functions
const fn = () => {};
const bound = fn.bind(null);
isFunction(bound)                 // true

// Built-in functions
isFunction(Math.max)              // true
isFunction(Promise.resolve)       // true

// Non-functions
isFunction(123)                   // false
isFunction('abc')                 // false
isFunction({})                    // false
isFunction(null)                  // false
isFunction(undefined)             // false
isFunction([])                    // false
isFunction(Symbol())              // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Classes are technically functions in JavaScript (typeof class X {} === 'function'), so they return true.
  • Async functions, generator functions, and bound functions are all considered functions by this helper.
  • This helper does not invoke the value; it only checks type.
  • Use normalizeFunction if you need to wrap or coerce values into callable functions.
  • Use validateFunction if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isInteger
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a finite integer. This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm integer types before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isInteger(value: unknown): value is number

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. This helper performs a strict typeof check and only returns true for finite integers.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a finite integer.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isInteger(42)          // true
isInteger(0)           // true
isInteger(-10)         // true
isInteger(3.14)        // false
isInteger(NaN)         // false
isInteger(Infinity)    // false
isInteger("123")       // false
isInteger(null)        // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper uses Number.isInteger internally, which rejects NaN, Infinity, and -Infinity.
  • BigInt values are not considered integers by this helper. Use isBigInteger for BigInt checks.
  • Use normalizeInteger if you need to convert values into integers.
  • Use validateInteger if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isIterable
docs.text: Checks whether a value is iterable. A value is iterable if it is not null or undefined and has a callable [Symbol.iterator] method. This matches the behavior of for...of, spread syntax, and Array.from.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text:
function isIterable<T = unknown>(value: unknown): value is Iterable<T>

Parameters

Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must implement the iterable protocol to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is iterable.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isIterable([1, 2, 3])        // true
isIterable('abc')            // true
isIterable(new Set())        // true

isIterable({})               // false
isIterable(123)              // false
isIterable(null)             // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper checks only for the presence of a callable [Symbol.iterator] method.
  • Array-like objects (objects with numeric length but without a [Symbol.iterator] method) are not considered iterable by this helper.
  • It does not attempt to call the iterator.
  • It does not treat array‑like objects as iterable unless they implement the iterator protocol.
  • Use validateIterable if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isJSON
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is a valid JSON value. This helper performs a strict, recursive structural check aligned with the ECMAScript JSON specification. It never throws and never mutates input.

A JSON value is one of:

  • null.
  • boolean.
  • A finite number (NaN, Infinity, and -Infinity are not allowed).
  • string.
  • An array of JSON values.

a plain object ({}) whose values are JSON values (objects with custom prototypes, for example, Date, Map, Set, or class instances, are rejected)

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isJSON(value: unknown): value is JSONValue

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must conform to JSON structural rules to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is JSON‑safe.
  • false otherwise.

Examples

isJSON(null)                     // true
isJSON(true)                     // true
isJSON(123)                      // true
isJSON('abc')                    // true
isJSON([1, 'a', null])           // true
isJSON({ a: 1, b: [true, null] }) // true

isJSON(NaN)                      // false
isJSON(Infinity)                 // false
isJSON(undefined)                // false
isJSON(() => {})                 // false
isJSON(new Date())               // false
isJSON({ a: undefined })         // false

// Circular references are rejected
const arr: unknown[] = [];
arr.push(arr);
isJSON(arr)                      // false

const obj: Record<string, unknown> = {};
obj['self'] = obj;
isJSON(obj)                       // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Rejects non‑finite numbers (NaN, Infinity).
  • Rejects objects with custom prototypes (including Date, Map, Set, class instances).
  • Rejects functions, symbols, bigint, and undefined.
  • Rejects circular structures.
  • This guard is structural, not behavioral — it does not call JSON.stringify.

docs.title: isMap
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a Map. This helper performs a strict instanceof check and never throws or mutates input. It accepts native Map instances, Map subclasses, and wrapper objects created with Object(...).

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isMap<K = unknown, V = unknown>(value: unknown): value is Map<K, V>

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a Map instance to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a Map.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isMap(new Map())          // true
isMap(new Map([['a', 1]]))// true
isMap(Object(new Map()))  // true

isMap({})                 // false
isMap([])                 // false
isMap(null)               // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper intentionally accepts Map wrapper objects because JavaScript treats them as genuine Map instances.
  • It does not treat plain objects or array‑likes as Maps.
  • Use validateMap if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isNonEmptyArray
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is a non‑empty array. This helper performs a strict Array check and verifies that the array contains at least one element.

It never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is an array with meaningful content before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isNonEmptyArray<T = unknown>(value: unknown): value is T[]

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: | Name | Data type | Description | | value | unknown | The value to check. Must be an array with at least one element to return true. |

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a non‑empty array.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isNonEmptyArray([1])        // true
isNonEmptyArray(['a'])      // true

isNonEmptyArray([])         // false
isNonEmptyArray('abc')      // false
isNonEmptyArray(null)       // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not validate the contents of the array.
  • Use normalizeNonEmptyArray if you need to coerce or default empty arrays.
  • Use validateNonEmptyArray if you need a Result<T[]> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isNonEmptyString
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a primitive, non‑empty string. This helper never throws and never mutates input. It performs a strict typeof check and does not trim, coerce, or normalize the value. Whitespace and zero‑width characters count as non‑empty. String objects (for example, new String("hello")) return false.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isNonEmptyString(value: unknown): value is string

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a primitive string with length > 0 to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true: If the value is a primitive string with length greater than 0.
  • false Otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isNonEmptyString("hello")            // true
isNonEmptyString(" ")                // true (whitespace counts as non-empty)
isNonEmptyString("\u200B")           // true (zero-width space counts as non-empty)
isNonEmptyString("")                 // false
isNonEmptyString(123)                // false
isNonEmptyString(null)               // false
isNonEmptyString(undefined)          // false
isNonEmptyString(new String("x"))    // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not trim whitespace.
  • Zero‑width characters still count as non‑empty.
  • Returns false for String objects (e.g., new String("x")).
  • Use normalizeNonEmptyString if you need trimming and conversion.
  • Use validateNonEmptyString if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isNonNegativeNumber
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is a non‑negative number. A non‑negative number is defined as a finite number greater than or equal to zero. Fractional values are allowed.

This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is suitable for ranges, durations, sizes, or any domain where zero or positive numeric values are valid.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isNonNegativeNumber(value: unknown): value is number

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: | Name | Data type | Description | | value | unknown | The value to check. Must be a finite number >= 0 to return true. |

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a finite number greater than or equal to zero.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isNonNegativeNumber(0)        // true
isNonNegativeNumber(3.14)     // true
isNonNegativeNumber(100)      // true

isNonNegativeNumber(-1)       // false
isNonNegativeNumber(NaN)      // false
isNonNegativeNumber(Infinity) // false

isNonNegativeNumber("0")      // false
isNonNegativeNumber(0n)       // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not coerce strings or other types into numbers.
  • Use normalizeNonNegativeNumber if you need coercion or fallback behavior.
  • Use validateNonNegativeNumber if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.
  • Big integers are intentionally rejected to avoid silent cross‑type numeric behavior.

docs.title: isNullOrUndefined
docs.text: Checks whether a value is null or undefined. This helper performs strict equality checks and never throws or mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is explicitly missing before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isNullOrUndefined(value: unknown): value is null | undefined

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Returns true only when the value is exactly null or undefined.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is null or undefined.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isNullOrUndefined(null)        // true
isNullOrUndefined(undefined)   // true

isNullOrUndefined(0)           // false
isNullOrUndefined('')          // false
isNullOrUndefined({})          // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper is useful when distinguishing "missing" from "present but falsy".
  • Use isNull or isUndefined if you need to check for one specific case.
  • Use normalizeNullish if you need to convert nullish values into defaults.
  • Use validateNullish if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isNull
docs.text: Checks whether a value is null. This helper performs a strict equality check and never throws or mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is explicitly null before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isNull(value: unknown): value is null

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. This helper returns true only when the value is exactly null.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is null.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isNull(null)        // true

isNull(undefined)   // false
isNull(0)           // false
isNull('')          // false
isNull({})          // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not treat undefined as null. Use isNullOrUndefined if you need to check for both.
  • Use normalizeNull if you need to convert values into null.
  • Use validateNull if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isNumber
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is a primitive number. This helper performs a strict typeof check and does not enforce finiteness.

It accepts NaN, Infinity, and -Infinity because they are still valid number primitives in JavaScript. This helper never throws and never mutates input.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isNumber(value: unknown): value is number

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. This helper returns true only for primitive numbers.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a primitive number.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isNumber(42)          // true
isNumber(0)           // true
isNumber(-3.14)       // true
isNumber(NaN)         // true
isNumber(Infinity)    // true

isNumber("123")       // false
isNumber(null)        // false
isNumber(1n)          // false
isNumber(new Number(5)) // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not check for finiteness. Use isFiniteNumber if you need to reject NaN, Infinity, and -Infinity.
  • Use isInteger if you need to confirm integer values.
  • Use normalizeNumber if you need to convert values into numbers.
  • Use validateNumber if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isObject
docs.text: Checks whether a value is an object, excluding null and arrays. This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is a non‑null, non‑array object before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isObject(value: unknown): value is object

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a non‑null, non‑array object to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is an object, not null, and not an array.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isObject({})                     // true
isObject({ a: 1 })               // true
isObject(Object.create(null))    // true

isObject([])                     // false
isObject(null)                   // false
isObject("hello")                // false
isObject(123)                    // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper excludes arrays by design.
  • Use isPlainObject if you need to confirm Object.getPrototypeOf(value) === Object.prototype.
  • Use normalizeObject if you need to ensure the value becomes an object.
  • Use validateObject if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isPlainObject
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a plain object. A plain object is one created with {} or new Object(), where the prototype is exactly Object.prototype. This helper excludes null, arrays, class instances, and objects with custom prototypes. It never throws and never mutates input.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isPlainObject(value: unknown): value is object

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a non‑null object whose prototype is exactly Object.prototype to return true

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a non‑null object with Object.prototype as its prototype.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isPlainObject({})                     // true
isPlainObject({ a: 1 })               // true
isPlainObject(new Object())           // true

isPlainObject([])                     // false
isPlainObject(null)                   // false
isPlainObject(Object.create(null))    // false
isPlainObject(new Date())             // false
isPlainObject(class X {})             // false
isPlainObject(new (class Y {})())     // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper is stricter than isObject.
  • Use isObject if you only need to exclude null and arrays.
  • Use normalizeObject if you need to ensure the value becomes an object.
  • Use validateObject if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isPort
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a valid TCP/UDP port number. A port is defined as an integer between 0 and 65535 (inclusive). This helper never throws and never mutates input. It performs strict type checks and does not coerce strings or other values into numbers.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isPort(value: unknown): value is number

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be an integer between 0 and 65535 (inclusive) to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is an integer within the valid port range.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isPort(0)        // true
isPort(80)       // true
isPort(65535)    // true

isPort(-1)       // false
isPort(70000)    // false
isPort(3.14)     // false
isPort("80")     // false
isPort(null)     // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not coerce strings (e.g., "80" is invalid).
  • This helper requires the value to be a primitive number.
  • Use normalizePort if you need to coerce values into ports.
  • Use validatePort if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isPositiveInteger
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is a positive integer. A positive integer is defined as a finite number with no fractional component and greater than zero.

This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is suitable for count‑based operations, array lengths, pagination, or any domain where only strictly positive whole numbers are valid.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isPositiveInteger(value: unknown): value is number

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a finite integer greater than zero to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a finite integer greater than zero.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isPositiveInteger(1)        // true
isPositiveInteger(42)       // true

isPositiveInteger(0)        // false
isPositiveInteger(-1)       // false
isPositiveInteger(1.5)      // false
isPositiveInteger(NaN)      // false
isPositiveInteger(Infinity) // false

isPositiveInteger("1")      // false
isPositiveInteger(1n)       // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not coerce strings or other types into numbers.
  • Use normalizePositiveInteger if you need coercion or fallback behavior.
  • Use validatePositiveInteger if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.
  • Big integers are intentionally rejected to avoid silent cross‑type numeric behavior.

docs.title: isPromise
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a Promise. This helper performs a strict instanceof check and never throws or mutates input. It accepts native Promise instances and Promise subclasses, but does not treat arbitrary thenables as Promises.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isPromise(value: unknown): value is Promise<unknown>

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Returns true only if the value is a native Promise instance or a subclass of Promise.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a Promise
  • false otherwise

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isPromise(Promise.resolve())     // true
isPromise(new Promise(() => {})) // true

isPromise({ then() {} })         // false
isPromise('promise')             // false
isPromise(null)                  // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper intentionally does not treat thenables as Promises.
  • It accepts Promise subclasses.
  • Use normalizePromise if you need to coerce values into Promises.
  • Use validatePromise if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isRecord
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is a record-like object with string keys.

A record is defined as:

  1. A non-null, non-array object.
  2. All own property keys are strings (symbols are not allowed).
  3. Objects with any prototype are accepted, including class instances and objects created with Object.create(null).

This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is suitable for string-keyed object operations before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isRecord(value: unknown): value is Record<string, unknown>

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a non-null, non-array object whose own keys are strings to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a non‑null, non‑array object.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isRecord({})                     // true
isRecord({ a: 1 })               // true
isRecord(Object.create(null))    // true
isRecord(new (class X {})())     // true

isRecord([])                     // false
isRecord(null)                   // false
isRecord("hello")                // false
isRecord(123)                    // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This guard is stricter than isObject because it rejects arrays.
  • It is stricter than isRecord because it also rejects symbol-keyed properties, fully aligning with TypeScript’s Record<string, unknown> type.
  • Use isPlainObject if you also need the prototype to be exactly Object.prototype.
  • Use normalizeRecord if you need to coerce values into records.
  • Use validateRecord if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isRegExp
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a regular expression. This helper performs a strict instanceof check and never throws or mutates input. It accepts both RegExp literals and RegExp objects created with new RegExp, including wrapper objects created with Object(...).

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isRegExp(value: unknown): value is RegExp

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a RegExp instance (including wrapper objects) to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a RegExp.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isRegExp(/abc/)              // true
isRegExp(new RegExp('abc'))  // true
isRegExp(Object(/abc/))      // true

isRegExp('/abc/')            // false
isRegExp('abc')              // false
isRegExp(null)               // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper intentionally accepts RegExp wrapper objects, because JavaScript treats them as genuine RegExp instances.
  • Strings that resemble regex literals (for example, /abc/) are not considered RegExp values.
  • Use normalizeRegExp if you need to convert strings into RegExp objects.
  • Use validateRegExp if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isSafeInteger
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is a safe integer. A safe integer is a finite integer whose absolute value does not exceed Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER.

This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is suitable for precise integer arithmetic, indexing, or any domain where JavaScript’s integer precision guarantees matter.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isSafeInteger(value: unknown): value is number

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a finite integer with a safe range to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a finite integer within the safe integer range.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isSafeInteger(0)                        // true
isSafeInteger(42)                       // true
isSafeInteger(Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER)  // true

isSafeInteger(Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER + 1) // false
isSafeInteger(1.5)                         // false
isSafeInteger(NaN)                          // false

isSafeInteger("1")                          // false
isSafeInteger(1n)                           // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not coerce strings or other types into numbers.
  • Use normalizeSafeInteger if you need coercion or fallback behavior.
  • Use validateSafeInteger if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.
  • Big integers are intentionally rejected to avoid silent cross‑type numeric behavior.
  • Safe integers are essential when you need guaranteed precision in JavaScript.

docs.title: isSet
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a Set. This helper performs a strict instanceof check and never throws or mutates input. It accepts native Set instances, Set subclasses, and wrapper objects created with Object(...).

docs.title: Signature
docs.text:
function isSet<T = unknown>(value: unknown): value is Set<T>

Parameters

Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a Set instance to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a Set.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isSet(new Set())          // true
isSet(new Set([1, 2, 3])) // true
isSet(Object(new Set()))  // true

isSet({})                 // false
isSet([])                 // false
isSet(null)               // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper intentionally accepts Set wrapper objects because JavaScript treats them as genuine Set instances.
  • It does not treat plain objects or array‑likes as Sets.
  • Use validateSet if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isString
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a primitive string. This helper never throws and never mutates input. It performs a strict typeof check and does not coerce values.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isString(value: unknown): value is string

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a string (primitive string) to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
• true if the value is a primitive string.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isString("hello")               // true
isString("")                    // true
isString(123)                   // false
isString(null)                  // false
isString(undefined)             // false
isString({})                    // false
isString([])                    // false
isString(new String("hello"))   // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not trim or modify the value.
  • This helper returns false for String objects (for example, new String("x")).
  • Use isNonEmptyString if you need to ensure the string is not empty.
  • Use normalizeString if you need to convert values into strings.

docs.title: isSymbol
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is a symbol. A symbol is a primitive value created using the Symbol function.

This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm symbol types before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isSymbol(value: unknown): value is symbol

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: | Name | Data type | Description | | value | unknown | The value to check. This helper returns true only for symbol primitives. |

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a symbol.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isSymbol(Symbol())          // true
isSymbol(Symbol('id'))      // true
isSymbol(Symbol.iterator)   // true

isSymbol(Object(Symbol()))  // false
isSymbol("abc")             // false
isSymbol(123)               // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper performs a strict typeof check and does not accept Symbol wrapper objects.
  • Use normalizeSymbol if you need to convert values into symbols.
  • Use validateSymbol if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isTimestamp
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a Unix timestamp in milliseconds. A timestamp is defined as a finite integer number representing milliseconds since the Unix epoch (1970‑01‑01T00:00:00Z). This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm timestamp values before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isTimestamp(value: unknown): value is number

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown true

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a finite integer timestamp.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isTimestamp(1700000000000)   // true
isTimestamp(0)               // true
isTimestamp(-1000)           // true (pre‑epoch)

isTimestamp(3.14)            // false
isTimestamp("1700000000000") // false
isTimestamp(NaN)             // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not accept fractional numbers or strings.
  • Negative timestamps are valid and represent dates before the Unix epoch.
  • Use normalizeTimestamp if you need to coerce values into timestamps.
  • Use validateTimestamp if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isTuple
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a tuple of a specific structure. A tuple is defined as an array with a fixed length where each element satisfies a corresponding guard. This helper is fully structural and never throws or mutates input.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text:
function isTuple<
    const Guards extends readonly ((value: unknown) => boolean)[]
>(
    value: unknown,
    guards: Guards,
): value is {
    [I in keyof Guards]:
        Guards[I] extends (value: unknown) => value is infer T ? T : unknown
}

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be an array of the same length as guards. guards Readonly array of guard functions One guard per tuple position. Each guard must accept unknown and return a boolean or a type predicate.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if value is an array of the same length as guards and each element passes its corresponding guard.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isTuple([1, 'x'], [isNumber, isString] as const);
// → true

isTuple([1, 2], [isNumber, isString] as const);
// → false

isTuple([1], [isNumber, isString] as const);
// → false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper is structural — it does not rely on TypeScript metadata.
  • The guards parameter must be provided as a tuple literal or a const tuple for correct inference.
  • Each guard is checked at runtime for safety; non-function guards cause the check to fail.
  • Use validateTuple if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isTypedArray
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is a TypedArray. This includes all built‑in typed array types such as Uint8Array, Float32Array, and BigInt64Array. This helper never throws and never mutates input.

You may optionally enforce a specific TypedArray constructor.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text:
function isTypedArray<T extends TypedArray = TypedArray>(
    value: unknown,
    expected?: { new (...args: unknown[]): T },
): value is T

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: | Name | Data type | Description | | value | unknown | The value to check. Must be a TypedArray to return true. | | expected | constructor | Optional. If provided, the value must be an instance of this specific TypedArray type. |

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a TypedArray.
  • true if the value is a TypedArray and matches the expected type.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isTypedArray(new Uint8Array())         // true
isTypedArray(new Float32Array())       // true
isTypedArray(new Uint8Array(), Uint8Array) // true
isTypedArray(new Uint8Array(), Float32Array) // false

isTypedArray([])                       // false
isTypedArray(new DataView(...))        // false
isTypedArray(null)                     // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper uses ArrayBuffer.isView and excludes DataView, matching the ECMAScript definition of TypedArray.
  • It accepts TypedArray subclasses and wrapper objects.
  • Use validateTypedArray if you need a Result<TypedArray> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isUndefined
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is undefined. This helper performs a strict equality check and never throws or mutates input.

Use it when you need to confirm that a value is explicitly undefined before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isUndefined(value: unknown): value is undefined

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. This helper returns true only when the value is exactly undefined.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is undefined.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isUndefined(undefined)   // true

isUndefined(null)        // false
isUndefined(0)           // false
isUndefined('')          // false
isUndefined({})          // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not treat null as undefined. Use isNullOrUndefined if you need to check for both.
  • Use normalizeUndefined if you need to convert values into undefined.
  • Use validateUndefined if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isWeakMap
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a WeakMap. This helper performs a strict instanceof check and never throws or mutates input. It accepts native WeakMap instances, WeakMap subclasses, and wrapper objects created with Object(...).

docs.title: Signature
docs.text:
function isWeakMap<K extends object = object, V = unknown>(
    value: unknown,
): value is WeakMap<K, V>

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a WeakMap instance to return true

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a WeakMap
  • false otherwise

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isWeakMap(new WeakMap())          // true
isWeakMap(Object(new WeakMap()))  // true

isWeakMap(new Map())              // false
isWeakMap({})                     // false
isWeakMap(null)                   // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper intentionally accepts WeakMap wrapper objects because JavaScript treats them as genuine WeakMap instances.
  • It does not treat plain objects or Maps as WeakMaps.
  • Use validateWeakMap if you need a Result<V> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isWeakSet
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a WeakSet. This helper performs a strict instanceof check and never throws or mutates input. It accepts native WeakSet instances, WeakSet subclasses, and wrapper objects created with Object(...).

docs.title: Signature
docs.text:
function isWeakSet<T extends object = object>(
    value: unknown,
): value is WeakSet<T>

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a WeakSet instance to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a WeakSet.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isWeakSet(new WeakSet())          // true
isWeakSet(Object(new WeakSet()))  // true

isWeakSet(new Set())              // false
isWeakSet({})                     // false
isWeakSet(null)                   // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper intentionally accepts WeakSet wrapper objects because JavaScript treats them as genuine WeakSet instances.
  • It does not treat plain objects or Sets as WeakSets.
  • Use validateWeakSet if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.
